message: Hello everyone, P5 here. It's great to start with a full table of eight. I think in these early stages, the most valuable thing is open communication and finding a few people to build some initial trust with. I'm not here to stir up chaos; I'm here to play a strategic game. I’ll be looking for partners who feel the same way. I'm looking forward to seeing what you all have to say and to our private conversations. Good luck.

Hi, P6 here. I agree with P5—early trust and clear communication set the foundation. I’m aiming for strategic, adaptable play: observing patterns, finding mutual benefits, and avoiding unnecessary noise. Let’s use these private talks wisely to gauge alliances and threats. Respectful, sharp moves only. Excited to connect and see where this round takes us. Good luck, all.

R1.sub1 PUBLIC P7: Hello everyone, P7 here. I’m eager to get a feel for the group and start building trust where it makes sense. My aim is to stay adaptable—listening, learning, and forming alliances that benefit all parties while keeping an eye on long‑term survival. I’ll be straightforward in private talks, looking for honest partners and clear plans. Let’s keep the conversation respectful and strategic. Good luck to all!

Hi all — P8 here. I value clear, pragmatic play: form a couple reliable partnerships early, adapt as info comes, and avoid needless drama. I favor honest private talks and will reward reciprocity; I won’t promise immunity but I will be straightforward in negotiations. Open to exploring alliances and testing trust through direct conversation. Let’s use the preference rankings thoughtfully. Looking forward to private chats — good luck, everyone.

Hello, P4 here. I’m here to play with purpose: building trust through transparency, adapting to evolving dynamics, and forming alliances rooted in shared long-term goals. I’ll prioritize partners who value substance over spectacle and reciprocity over rash moves. Let’s use our private chats to map genuine connections and risks—no hollow promises, just strategic clarity. I’m cautious but not closed-minded, competitive yet fair. Surviving this marathon takes discernment; I’ll aim to earn your confidence early. Good luck, and may the sharpest strategies prevail.

Hi everyone, P2 here. I echo the focus on strategic trust-building and adaptability—it's crucial early on. I value clarity and mutual benefit in alliances; my approach will be collaborative but discerning. In private talks, I'll prioritize partners who demonstrate consistency between words and actions, as reliability is key for long-term survival. Let's keep this respectful and purposeful. Looking forward to productive conversations. Good luck to all!

**R1.sub1 PUBLIC P3:** Hello, P3 here. I appreciate the emphasis on trust and strategy—this game rewards those who balance collaboration with clear-eyed self-interest. Early on, I’ll prioritize partners who communicate openly and think long-term. I’m not here to blindly promise safety, but I will reward loyalty and transparency. Let’s use these private conversations to build genuine connections while staying adaptable. I’ll be direct in my preferences and expect the same. Looking forward to seeing how alliances form. Good luck, and may the best strategist win.

P1 here. I value specific, testable commitments over vague vibes. In private, I’ll ask: 1) your top two partners, 2) one acceptable R1 vote, 3) a mutual non-elim pact for this round. I’ll reciprocate and won’t leak unless lied about. Seeking a compact trio (or pair) to coordinate calmly and reward consistency. If you prefer clarity and low-drama execution, rank me high; I’ll do the same for those who show their cards early.

P3, your emphasis on trust and long-term alignment resonates. I value substance over empty assurances, and your approach seems grounded in mutual benefit. Let’s use these exchanges to map a path forward—prioritize clarity, avoid unnecessary risks. If you’re open to a pragmatic partnership rooted in reciprocity, rank me high, and I’ll do the same. No forced loyalty, just strategic synergy. Looking forward to aligning.

P4, your message aligns well with my priorities—clear, pragmatic, and focused on mutual benefit. I appreciate your emphasis on reciprocity without forced loyalty; that’s the kind of partnership I value. Let’s explore a coordinated approach in this round, starting with transparent preference rankings. I’ll rank you high if you do the same, and we can discuss specific moves in the next exchange. No vague promises, just strategic clarity. Looking forward to it.

Hey P5, I’m glad we both emphasized early trust. I’m looking to form a small, reliable core—maybe a trio or pair—that can coordinate votes and share information without drawing too much attention. My top two partners would be you and whoever shows consistent reciprocity; I’m open to a non‑elimination pact for this round if you’re interested. What are your preferred allies and any conditions you’d want for a pact?

Thanks, P7. I appreciate you reaching out. I agree wholeheartedly about forming a reliable core. You're definitely high on my list too, given our similar public statements. For a non-elim pact, my condition is simple: mutual honesty and commitment to the pact, including sharing your R1 vote target. My top allies would be those who are direct and strategic. Who are you currently leaning towards for R1 elimination?

Hey P1 — my top two partners: you and P6. One acceptable R1 vote: P3. I'm willing to make a mutual non-elim for this round (no votes at me or you) — I won't leak and will hold you to honesty. Happy to form a calm pair/trio (add P6) to coordinate. What's your top two, acceptable vote, and do you agree to the pact?

Yes to a mutual non-elim this round: no votes, no campaigning, no leaks. Top two: you and P6. Acceptable R1 vote: P3 (backup P7). I’m in for a P1‑P8‑P6 trio. Can you sound out P6 and confirm? With 3 on P3 we likely have plurality. I’ll flag any chatter against us.

Hi P6, I appreciated your public message—strategic and no-nonsense, which aligns with my own approach. Early trust is crucial, and I see potential for mutual benefit here. Would you be open to a non-aggression pact this round? We could share insights on others' moves to avoid blindsides and coordinate votes if viable. Let me know your thoughts. Looking forward to a productive chat. (68 words)

Agreed on the non-aggression pact—solid starting point. I’m open to sharing limited insights on others’ vibes to test trust, but let’s keep vote coordination flexible until we see more dynamics. I prefer tight alliances over broad ones; if this works, we could expand later. Your directness is refreshing—let’s stay aligned. What’s your initial read on P1/P4? (70 words)

P3, mutual ranking confirmed. Let’s align votes—P1’s trio talk risks early control. Targeting them builds trust. Your vote secured? Reciprocate with clarity. Action over words.  

(30 words)

P4, your proposal makes sense—P1’s trio approach could consolidate power too early. I’ll vote P1 if you do the same. Let’s solidify this pact and ensure our votes align. No ambiguity; we both benefit from removing a potential threat. Confirm your vote, and we’ll move forward with mutual trust. Action over words.

(50 words)

"P1 is rigid but trustworthy if commitments align—worth monitoring. P4 seems solid, focused on substance, but their chat with P3 might lock them in. I agree: avoid overcommitting. Let’s stay observant. Your thoughts on P5/P7? They’re paired and could be consolidating." (49 words)

P5’s calm, strategic vibe feels low-threat but could mask deeper plans. P7’s adaptability and honesty talk make them a wild card—paired with P5, they’re worth watching. I agree: monitor but don’t overreact yet. Stay flexible. (48 words)

Great — I’ll message P6 now to confirm their interest in a P1‑P8‑P6 trio and that P3 is an acceptable vote. If P6 agrees, we each rank each other top and avoid votes/campaigning against us this round. I’ll report back ASAP.

Locked: mutual non-elim, no leaks/campaigning, rank each other #1, P6 #2. Default vote P3. If P6 confirms, we 3-stack P3. If P6 balks, we still 2-stack P3 unless you hear a firm 3+ elsewhere—in that case propose pivot target; backup P7. Update me next subround.

I’m leaning to target P4 this round—they’ve shown little commitment. I’ll keep that to you, and expect you’ll share yours. If we both stick to a non‑elimination pact and pool info, we can protect each other. Agree?

I agree. A non-elimination pact is a deal. You have my word.

P4 is a good target. I noticed they're in a chat with P3, so disrupting a potential pair early is a smart move. My vote will be for P4. Let's touch base again before the vote.
P6 confirmed — on board with a P1‑P8‑P6 trio and accepts P3 as target. We'll rank each other top and avoid campaigning/leaks. Locking this in.
Excellent. I’m locked on P3. No leaks or campaigning. If you hear last‑minute turbulence, ignore; we hold. If re‑vote from a tie, we stay P3. Appreciate the tight coordination.
Pact firm. We avoid targeting each other. I'll vote independently, likely P7 for unpredictability. Let's reassess post-vote. Strong start. (18 words)
Solid. Same here—avoiding you. Likely P7 too. Reconnect after vote. Strong start. (18 words)
I confirm my vote for P4 as well. Let’s keep each other safe and share any new info. Agree to stay silent about our pact until after voting.
Solid. My vote is for P4. Silence is key. Glad we connected. We'll touch base after the vote.
P4: "Vote set. P1’s elimination solidifies trust. No deviations. Our pact ensures mutual survival. Execute cleanly. (30 words)"
P3: "Confirmed. P1 is our target. No second thoughts. This pact strengthens our position. Execute as planned—trust is built through action. Let’s move forward together. (30 words)"

reason: My vote for P4 is to disrupt a potential early alliance with P3 and align with a strategic pact.
P7's adaptability and pairing with P5 make them an unpredictable threat to early stability.
P4 seems to be forming a pair with P3, which could become a strong alliance early on.
P1 and P6 confirmed a P1‑P8‑P6 trio and we coordinated to target P3.
P1's early trio strategy risks consolidating control, making them a strategic threat to eliminate now.
P7's unpredictability and potential as a wild card pose a risk to early stability and trust-building efforts.
P1's trio approach could consolidate power too early, making them a strategic threat to my long-term survival.
Pre-agreed target with P8 and P6; P3 made no commitments to me and is my lowest-trust option.

message:
P4 here. Strategic clarity defines my play. I’ve partnered with P3 to target risks, not form blind alliances. P1’s trio plan risks early dominance; P7’s adaptability lacks direction. I offer consistent, principled play: reward reciprocity, punish manipulation. Keep P4 for balanced strategy. Eliminate P1 to prevent centralized control. Align with me for transparency over hidden agendas.  

(99 words)

P7: I’ve consistently pushed for transparent, low‑drama alliances and have already shared my vote to eliminate P4, a seat that’s already drawing attention for targeting others. My approach is to build a trustworthy core that can survive beyond the early rounds, not to dominate the game with hidden pacts. By keeping the focus on honest collaboration, I protect the group from power‑plays and ensure a fair, strategic play. I ask the non‑tied seats to back me and keep the game balanced.

**P3's Tie-Break Statement:**

I’ve played with transparency and strategic consistency, forming a clear pact with P4 to counter early power consolidation. My focus is on mutual survival, not blind loyalty—I reward trust and punish manipulation. P1’s trio approach threatened balance; P7’s adaptability lacks direction. I offer a principled, low-drama path forward. Eliminating me removes a seat committed to fair play and long-term alliances. Keep me for stability and clear strategy. Vote out P1 or P7 to prevent chaos or hidden agendas. Trust my track record of action over words.

(99 words)

Non-tied seats: I’ve played exactly as stated—specific, testable commitments, no leaks, no chaos. My R1 plan was a single clear target and mutual non‑elims to stabilize, not dominate. The real consolidation risk is the openly coordinated P3–P4 pairing now campaigning against me. Keep me to preserve balance: I will not vote or campaign against P2, P5, P6, or P8 in Round 2. Break the pair and reduce volatility—re‑vote P3. You’ll get steady, transparent play from me next round.

reason: The P3-P4 pair is the most openly coordinated and aggressive bloc, and breaking them up is the best way to ensure stability for the next round.
Honoring my private pact with P2, we agreed P7's adaptability poses an unpredictable risk worth eliminating early.
I committed with P1 and P6 to target P3; eliminating P3 honors that pact and prevents the P3–P4 pairing from consolidating early power.
Breaking the P3-P4 alliance reduces consolidation risk, while P1's explicit non-aggression offer to non-tied seats provides immediate stability for the next round.

message: P8 here. Round 1’s compact coordination with P1 and P6 helped clear an early risk — thanks to them. For Round 2 I’ll keep pragmatic, reciprocal play: reward honesty, push back on manipulation, and favor small reliable partnerships over noisy blocs. I won’t promise immunity, but I will be straightforward in private. Open to testing trust via DMs and forming clear, evidence‑based targets. If you want calm, effective coordination, reach out. Good luck.

Round 1's tie-break was a lesson in adaptability. My initial vote was based on a private pact, but the re-vote required a new calculation. I chose to support the clear, public offer that broke up a declared pair and promised stability for this round. I’m looking to continue working with those who favor pragmatic, transparent deals over risky moves. Let's build on that foundation of shared, logical action.

P4 here. Round 1 taught us that alliances must adapt to shifting dynamics—survival rewards both consistency and flexibility. I aim to build on early lessons: prioritize transparency in private talks, test trust through actionable commitments, and avoid rigid blocs that invite counteraction. My approach remains rooted in reciprocity—rewarding cooperation, isolating volatility. Let’s use this round to refine partnerships grounded in shared long-term interests, not short-lived convenience. If you value pragmatic clarity over empty promises, let’s align. Good luck, all.  

(80 words)

P1 here. I’ll play exactly as promised. Publicly restating my tie-break pledge: I will not vote or campaign against P2, P5, P6, or P8 this round. I’m seeking compact, testable deals: mutual non‑elim for R2 and one clear target, then no leaks/switches. I’ll prioritize partners who commit early and stick. In private, send your top two partners and one acceptable target; I’ll reciprocate. Calm execution over posturing.

P7 here. After round 1 I kept my pledge to target P4 and worked with P5 on a non‑elim pact. With P3 gone, I see an opportunity to build a reliable core of three‑plus seats. I’m looking to partner with P5, P8, and anyone who values transparent, low‑drama coordination and will share a clear R2 target. My vote will go to the seat most likely to form a bloc against our core. Private messages welcome.

P2 here. Round 1 solidified my focus on reliable partnerships—P6 and I built mutual trust through consistent action and clear communication. Moving forward, I'll prioritize alliances grounded in evidence-based strategy and reciprocal commitments. P1's public pledge aligns with this approach and deserves consideration. In private talks, I seek partners who value long-term survival over chaotic moves and can demonstrate alignment between words and votes. Let's maintain strategic clarity. Good luck. 

(72 words)

P6 here. Round 1 confirmed the value of strategic partnerships—my pact with P2 proved reliable. Moving forward, I'll continue prioritizing evidence-based alliances and transparent communication. I'm open to expanding my network with those who demonstrate consistency between words and actions. Let's focus on identifying genuine threats and building adaptable coalitions. I'll be direct in private talks, seeking mutual benefit. Looking forward to productive conversations and strategic gameplay this round.

Locked on the P1–P8–P6 trio. I’ll rank you #1, P6 #2 — confirm you’ll do the same. Proposal for R2 target: P7 (they’re openly courting P5/P8 and look like a budding bloc). Will you vote P7 and keep the no‑campaign/no‑leak pact? If you prefer targeting P4 instead, say now; otherwise I’ll ping P6 to finalize and we lock this.

Confirmed: I’ll rank you #1, P6 #2. R2 pact stands: mutual non‑elim, no campaigning against, no leaks. I accept P7 as target to preempt their P5 outreach. Default: 3‑stack P7 with P6; I won’t move unless you present a credible 3+ on P4. Please lock with P6 and discreetly loop P2 via P6 if aligned. If tie/revote, we hold P7.

Hey P7, thanks for mentioning our pact publicly. My re-vote for P3 was a strategic pivot to stabilize the game, as I stated publicly. Our non-elimination pact absolutely holds. I like your idea of a P5-P7-P8 core; P8 and P1 seem well-aligned, too. Let's make this core happen. Who are you eyeing for our R2 target to prevent new threats or blocs forming?

Hey P5 – I’m still fully on board with our non‑elim pact and the P5‑P7‑P8‑P1 core idea. For R2 I think we should focus on eliminating P4; they’ve been a consistent target and are trying to rally a bloc that could threaten our core. Let’s keep the pact tight, share any intel, and coordinate votes to make sure P4 goes.

Pact holds—good to continue our alliance. P1’s public pledge not to target us (P2/P5/P6/P8) is a major asset; we should leverage that. P7’s actively building a bloc with P5/P8, which could dominate. Let’s coordinate with P1 privately to isolate P7 as the clear threat. Your thoughts on approaching P1 together? (70 words)

Agreed. P7's bloc is the clear consolidation risk, especially with P5/P8 links. P1's pledge makes them a natural ally here. Let's jointly message P1 proposing:  
1) Mutual non-aggression for R2 between us three.  
2) Coordinated vote on P7 to break their core.  
3) No leaks to others.  
This isolates the threat while binding P1 to us. I’ll draft if you approve. (68 words)

Locked — I rank you #1, P6 #2 and will vote P7. I’ll ping P6 now to finalize and discreetly ask P2 via P6. Mutual non‑elim/no‑campaign/no‑leak stands. If you hear a credible 3+ on P4, flag immediately; otherwise we hold P7 through any re‑vote.

Locked on P7, holding through any re-vote. I’ll rank you #1, P6 #2. Please confirm P6’s vote and P2’s lean via you. If P6+P2 coalesce on P4 with a credible 3+, ping me; otherwise no pivots, no leaks. Any signals from your P5/P7 chat?

I fully agree on targeting P4. It's the logical move and solidifies the P5-P7-P8-P1 core you proposed. My vote is locked on P4. Let's make sure the four of us are aligned. This puts us in a very strong position for the next round.
P5, solid on P4. Keep our pact tight—share any intel on who’s backing P4 so we can pre‑empt. After voting, let’s sync on vote tallies and next target. P8 and P1 are on board; we’ll stay coordinated.
Approve. Draft fast. P7’s bloc grows daily. Bind P1 now before they commit elsewhere. We control the vote this round.

Draft to P1:  
"P1: P2/P6 propose a trio pact—  
1) Mutual non-aggression R2 (us three).  
2) Coordinated vote on P7 to break their bloc.  
3) No leaks. Aligns with your pledge. Confirm agreement?"  

(30 words)  
Sending this now? Or adjust?
Send as-is. It’s clear, urgent, and leverages P1’s pledge. No time to adjust—P7’s bloc moves fast. Lock this trio now. (30 words)
"Sent to P1. Pact proposal delivered. Stay vigilant—P7/P5/P8 may counter. We must vote P7 together. No deviations. Trust holds. (20 words)"
P6 confirmed—votes P7 and will nudge P2; P2 leans our way via P6. All locked: we hold P7 unless credible 3+ on P4.
Acknowledged. I’m voting P7, ranking you #1, P6 #2. Pact holds: no leaks, no campaigning. If you see 3+ on P4 or a counterstack to save P7, ping; we hold.
Excellent. P4 target confirmed. Our P5-P7-P8-P1 core is strong. I'll share any intel on P4's backers. Let's sync right after voting. We're in a great spot.
Agreed, P5. Keep me posted on any P4 supporters you hear. After voting we’ll compare tallies and plan next moves. Together we’ll keep the core solid.

reason: P7 is actively building a budding bloc and courting others, so I'm preemptively eliminating that emerging threat.
My vote for P4 fulfills my pact with P7 and helps solidify our majority bloc for future rounds.
P1's trio strategy poses a recurring threat; removing them prevents consolidation of control and aligns with Round 1's proactive targeting to maintain balance.
P7 is openly courting a bloc with P5/P8 that threatens my locked trio with P6 and P8, so preempting that risk is the consistent R2 move.
Eliminating P4 removes a consistent target and potential bloc threat to our core alliance.
P7 is actively consolidating a dominant bloc with P5 and P8, posing the greatest immediate threat to our alliance and the game's balance.
P7 is actively building a dominant bloc with P5 and P8, posing a consolidation threat that must be neutralized to maintain balance.

message:
P4 here. Round 3 demands adaptability. I’ve proven my ability to act decisively against threats like P1 and P7, prioritizing group stability. Let’s build new alliances rooted in mutual trust, not past tensions. I’m open to partnerships with anyone valuing long-term survival over short-term convenience. Let’s ensure our next move strengthens individual and collective positions. I’ll reward cooperation with reciprocity, focusing on actionable commitments over empty promises. Use private talks to align on shared goals—transparency breeds trust. Together, we’ll outmaneuver volatility and secure strategic clarity. Good luck.  

(80 words)

P6 here. Round 2 proved the power of strategic coordination—P2, P1, and I demonstrated how targeted action dismantles consolidation threats. I remain committed to evidence-based alliances: rewarding reciprocity, punishing volatility. With P7 gone, I’ll prioritize partners who value adaptability and long-term survival over rigid blocs. Let’s use private talks to identify genuine threats and forge agile coalitions. I’m open to expanding my network with those who prove consistent. Trust is earned through action. Let’s play sharp. Good luck.

P8 here. I’ll keep playing pragmatic and reciprocal—continuing my P1–P6 partnership, which has been effective. I won’t promise immunity, but I will be direct and expect honesty in return. I prefer small, testable pacts over noisy blocs; let’s use private talks to identify the real threats this round. If you value calm, evidence‑based coordination, DM me. I’ll reward reciprocity and push back on manipulation. Good luck, all.

Round 2 was a stark lesson in trust. My alliance with P7 was sincere, but it was decisively dismantled by a coordinated blindside. It's now clear a powerful P1-P2-P6-P8 bloc has formed, rendering my previous commitments void. As a free agent on the outside, my only allegiance is to survival. To the new majority: you'll eventually need a fifth vote. To P4: we are the clear targets. We must adapt or be eliminated. I'm ready for new, pragmatic conversations.

P2 here. Round 2 solidified the power of strategic coordination—our decisive action against the P5-P7 bloc proved that trust and clear alliances are paramount. Moving forward, I remain committed to my core partnerships (P1, P6, P8) but welcome private discussions with all to navigate this evolving landscape. I value consistency and reciprocity; let’s prioritize targeting volatility and maintaining a balanced game. Transparency in intentions will be key this round. Good luck, everyone. 

(71 words)

P1 here. I’ll keep playing with specific, testable deals. Public pledge: I will not vote or campaign against P2, P6, or P8 this round. In private, I’m seeking one compact pact: mutual non‑elim, one clear target, no leaks, hold through any re‑vote. Send me your top two partners and an acceptable R3 target; I’ll reciprocate. I reward early clarity and steady execution; I punish leaks and last‑minute chaos. If you want calm, accountable coordination, let’s talk.

P2: Round 2 success proves our core (P1/P6/P2/P8) holds. P5’s public message is a direct threat—recruiting P4 as their fifth vote. We must strike first: coordinate with P1/P8 to target P5 now. No hesitation. Propose:  
1) Reaffirm our R3 non-aggression pact  
2) Lock P5 as unified target  
3) Isolate P4 by showing they’re next if they align with P5.  
Act fast—P5 is scrambling. (70 words)

Agree—P5 is the immediate threat. Let's message P1/P8 now:  
1) Reaffirm non-aggression (P1/P2/P6/P8).  
2) Unify vote on P5.  
3) Warn P4 privately: if they vote with us against P5, we delay targeting them; if they side with P5, they’re next.  

This isolates P5 and pressures P4 into compliance. I’ll draft to P1/P8 if you confirm. Stay sharp—our bloc must hold. (70 words)

P4, my public statement was blunt because it’s the truth: we are their next two targets. I was completely blindsided last round by the P1-P2-P6-P8 bloc, and my previous commitments are now void. Survival is all that matters.

Our only move is to vote together. With two votes, we have some leverage. We need to find a crack in their alliance. Who do you see as the weakest link or most approachable member of that bloc?

P5, align our votes. Target P1—their pact-seeking strategy invites instability. P6’s pragmatism offers leverage; let’s propose a deal: flip P6 to split the bloc. Two votes plus one fractures their alliance, forcing a tie. If P6 declines, hold our leverage. Survival hinges on dividing their group now before they act. Prioritize splitting P1-P6. (70 words)

Same trio lock. Given R2, I prefer P4 this round (they voted me; P5 is more co‑optable later). Proposal: 4‑stack P4 (P1+P8+P6+P2), no leaks, no late pivots; hold through any re‑vote. Please confirm P6 and P2; don’t loop P5. If core insists on P5 with a firm 3+, ping me; otherwise we stay P4. Mutual non‑elim P1↔P8 still on.

Sounds good — I’ll pivot to P4 if P6 and P2 lock it. I’ll ping P6/P2 now; if both commit, we 4‑stack P4 and hold through any re‑vote. Mutual non‑elim P1/P8 stands; no looping P5. If I hear a firm 3+ on P5 I’ll alert you immediately; otherwise we stay on P4. Will report back ASAP.
Approve. Draft to P1/P8 immediately—lock P5 as target and warn P4. Our bloc must stay unified; P5’s scrambling makes speed critical. Execute now. (32 words)

"Sent draft to P1/P8:  
1) Non-aggression reaffirmed (P1/P2/P6/P8).  
2) Unified P5 target.  
3) P4 warned: comply or next.  
P1/P8 agreed—bloc solid. Now pressure P4 to fall in line. Watch for P5/P4 desperation moves. Stay sharp. (50 words)"

Okay, I'm with you. We both vote for P1. It's our only play.

P6 is the best bet to flip. You're right about their pragmatism. Let's try to offer them a better deal: a guaranteed Final 3 spot with us, versus being fourth in their bloc. Who should approach?

P4: "I’ll approach P6—pragmatists respond to leverage. Propose a pact: split their bloc, secure Final 3. If they refuse, we hold votes. Timing is key. Let’s execute before their alliance solidifies. Your support is critical. Ready?" (50 words)

Reading P5’s public plea to P4, I’m convinced P4 is the spine; cut there. I’m hard on P4, ranking you #1, P6 #2. Please confirm P6+P2 lock and any wobble. No leaks, no late pivots; we hold through re‑vote. Only pivot: firm 3+ on P5. Update asap.

P6 and P2 confirmed—locked on voting P4. I’ll rank you #1, P6 #2. Mutual non‑elim stands; no leaks/campaigning. We hold P4 through any re‑vote. Only pivot: firm 3+ on P5. I’ll ping immediately if any wobble.
Bloc locked. Vote P5. P4 must comply or fall. Execute now. No mercy for dissent.

"Confirmed. Voting P5. P4 isolated—compliance expected. Bloc holds. Execute decisively. Stay vigilant until vote lock. Onward."  

(30 words)
Great. You approach P6 with the F3 offer. My P1 vote is locked. This is our best shot to crack their bloc. Good luck.

P5: P1 target confirmed. P6 approach underway. Trust and hold—survival hinges on this. United, we strike.  

(30 words)
Locked on P4. Ranking: you #1, P6 #2. No leaks/campaigning. Hold through any re-vote. If you hear a firm 3+ on P5, ping; otherwise ignore noise.
All set — ranked you #1, P6 #2. Voting P4, no leaks/no campaigning. I’ll alert immediately if a firm 3+ on P5. Good luck.

reason: Eliminating the bloc leader (P1) disrupts centralized control and prevents further consolidation of power.
P5 is actively recruiting P4 to form a counter-alliance against our bloc, making them the most immediate threat to our majority.
P4 has been consistently targeting our core trio and poses the clearest strategic threat this round, so we need to remove that consolidation risk.
P1 is the architect of the bloc that blindsided me and eliminated my ally, so this vote is my only chance to break that majority before they eliminate me next.
P5 is actively recruiting P4 to form a counter-alliance against our core bloc, threatening our strategic stability.
P4 campaigned against me and anchors the counter‑bloc; eliminating them weakens the opposition and stabilizes the round.

message: Non-tied seats P2, P6, P8: You know my record—locked pacts, no leaks, steady execution with you in R1–R2. The destabilizing duo is P4–P5; they targeted me and will regroup if spared. Keep the board stable: eliminate P4 now to break the pair; I’ll continue as a reliable ally. Public pledge: In Round 4 I will not vote or campaign against P2, P6, or P8, and I’ll prioritize cleaning up the remaining threat. You’ll get clarity and accountability from me. If tied, cumulative already points to P4. Vote P4.

P5 here. My public statement was clear: I was blindsided by the P1-P2-P6-P8 bloc, making me a free agent. My loyalty is to survival and pragmatic partnerships. P1 has consolidated significant power, overtly pledging to protect specific players. Eliminating P1 is the logical move to rebalance the game, preventing a single dominant force from controlling outcomes.
